STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 28, 2021
TaSeanda Johnson
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
RE: License #: CP820201497
Wayne County DHHS - Western
27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Dear Ms. Johnson:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
September 20, 2021. Due to the violations, of applicable licensing rules, policies and
ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing statutes rules are also violations of the ISEP requirements.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary
action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248)860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Licensee #: CP820201497
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: TaSeanda Johnson, Administrator
Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Wayne County DHHS - Western
Facility Address: 27540 Michigan Avenue
Inkster, MI 48141
Facility Telephone #: (313) 934-8910
Original Issuance Date: 05/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Four of 37 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One employee’s record did not contain a 2020 or current
2021 annual performance evaluation.
 A second and third employee’s record did not show
documentation of a 2021 performance evaluation due by
9/1/2021 and 9/14/2021 respectively.
 A fourth record showed documentation of an incomplete
performance evaluation for 9/1/2020-8/31/2021. The
supervisor had yet to complete the evaluation.
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
One of 29 new employee records reviewed showed a October
2017 OWI (Operating While Impaired)- Intoxication charge and
subsequent OWVI(Operating While Visibly Impaired) conviction.
The record showed documentation of an acknowledgement of
the conviction form signed by the employee, but not a written
evaluation by the chief administrator or designee of the
employee’s conviction.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
4

(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s annual medical examination due by 7/27/2021 was
completed 29 days late on 8/25/2021. The agency reported the
teen’s lack of cooperation impacted the timeliness of the
medical examination.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a):
Three of five Initial Service Plans (ISP) reviewed were late by:
 One day.
 Three days.
 13 days.
(b):
One of 15 Updated Service Plans (USP) reviewed were one day
late.
Repeat Violations Renewal 2019.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
Five of five ISPs reviewed did not show documentation of (c) as
required by the rule.
R 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster
parent.
5

In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child’s
initial service plan did not show documentation of the behavior
management plan to be used by the foster parent.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(b),
shall include all of the following information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any changes
made since the previous plan and which is to be used by the
foster parents.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the child’s
updated service plan did not show documentation of the
behavior management plan to be used by the foster parent.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.33 c Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services
Of 20 service plans reviewed, three, where the youth was 14
years of age or older, did not show documentation of the youth’s
signature.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
ISEP 6.49 Medical passports (Commitment 85).
At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
6

1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Three of eight open child records reviewed did not show
compliance, as required by the standard.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
Policy 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following tables…
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed that the child’s semi-annual
transitional meeting due by 4/26/2021 was completed
late on 6/7/2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 2/12/2021-3/9/2021 ISP. An FTM was
completed after the period on 3/11/2021. This same
record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
child’s 3/10/2021-6/7/2021. An FTM was completed after
the period on 3/9/2021.
 A third record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 10/28/2020-1/25/2021; 1/26/2021-4/23/2021,
or 4/24/2021-7/28/2021 USP.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 6/3/2021-7/2/2021 ISP.
 A fifth record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105
form for a documented 2/23/2021 FTM. Nor
documentation of an FTM for the child’s 3/6/2021-
7

5/18/2021 USP. An FTM was completed after the period
on 5/27/2021. Additionally, this record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the child’s 5/19/2021-
7/30/2021 USP. An FTM was completed after the period
on 8/26/2021.
 A sixth record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 11/1/2020-1/29/2021 or 1/30/2021-4/29/2021
USP.
 A seventh record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 7/19/2021-8/17/2021 ISP. An FTM was
completed after the period on 8/24/2021. Additionally,
this record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105
form for a reported 8/27/2021 FTM.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020, Renewal 2019.
Policy-722-6H Documentation of contacts.
Two of eight open child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One child’s record showed supervisor/worker meetings
for 2/26/2021, 3/30/2021 and 4/20/2021 were not listed in
the child’s 1/26/2021-4/23/2021 USP.
 A second child’s record showed recorded 2/18/2021,
2/25/2021 and 3/4/2021 home visits, as well as social
work contacts of 2/12/2021, 2/16/2021 and 2/17/2021
were not listed in the child’s ISP.
Policy-722-8C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee
Six of 20 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 Two child records did not show documentation of the
foster parent’s/caregiver’s signature on the child’s
respective ISP’s parent agency treatment plan
agreement (PATPA).
 A third record showed the child’s 4/21/2021-7/22/2021
PATPA was not signed by the foster parent/caregiver.
 A fourth record showed the child’s 11/1/2020-1/29/2021;
1/30/2021-4/29/2021 and 4/30/2021-7/28/2021
respective PATPA was not signed by the foster
parent/caregiver.
8

Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.
Policy-722-8E Foster care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change:
Case Closure/ Change in placement:
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure or a placement change.
Two of three open foster child records and two of three closed
child records did not show compliance.
 One open child’s record did not show documentation of a
DHS-69 for the child’s return from AWOL to a caregiver’s
home or DHS-69 of a second AWOL (7/16//2021-
7/22/2021) or placement thereafter to Vista Maria.
 A second open child’s record did not show a DHS-69 for
the child’s 4/8/2021 AWOL, 5/4/2021 placement at
Methodist Children home, or 5/13/2021 return to a
relative’s home.
 A third and fourth closed child’s record did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the respective child’s
1/6/2021 and 7/13/2021 case closure.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12208 Job description & R400.12212(4) Personnel records.
 The agency was apprised it shall consistently have and document a job
description and an orientation record for all staff person, inclusive of
Interns.
ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS documentation (Commitment 22)
 The agency was apprised it shall consistently upload all required case
documents.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
9

 Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
That corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2020 Interim inspection where it
received the following citations:
 R400.12212(e)(i)(ii) for Personnel records, related to a late initial ICHAT
for two Interns.
 R400.12212(2)(h) for Personnel records, related to a late central record
clearance for two Interns.
 R400.12413(1)(d) (i-iii) for Medical and dental care policy, related to
missing immunizations for two children.
 R400.12413(2) for Medical and dental policy, related to missing medical
examination documentation for two children.
 R400.12418(5) for Development of services plans.
 R400.12505 (2)(b) for Supervision, related to an independent living youth.
 R400.12510(2) for Independent living contract, related to an independent
living youth.
 ISEP 4.22 for MISACWIS documentation.
 ISEP 6.43 for Mental health screening within 30 days of entry into foster
care.
 ISEP 6.49 for Medical passport.
 Policy 722-6B for Family team meeting.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan, but it was not totally
effective at fulfilling it. The agency received repeat violations related to medical
passports and family team meetings.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
10

September 27, 2021
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 28, 2021
________________________________________
Date
Area Manager
